hero.title: Community-Led Universal Quality Palliative Care Grid

about.title: About Kerala Care
about.description: Kerala palliative care grid is a community-based healthcare network where trained volunteers and medical professionals collaborate to support people with Serious Health Related suffering through home-based care, incorporating medical, social, and emotional support for both patients and families. Monitored by the State Health Authority.

legacy.title: Legacy of Compassion
legacy.quote: A people’s movement should be initiated to ensure quality palliative care for all individuals and families in need, bridging the gap between rural and urban areas, and guaranteeing care without any distinction between APL (Above Poverty Line) and BPL (Below Poverty Line) categories.
legacy.author: Pinarayi Vijayan, Chief Minister of Kerala

questions.question: What exactly is palliative care?
questions.answer: Palliative care is the total care of patients and their families, suffering from life limiting illness, aiming to reduce physical, psychological, social and  spiritual suffering and improve the quality of their lives.

questions.question: When should someone consider palliative care?
questions.answer: Anyone who needs assistance to get up from bed, or is home bound due to any illness or is undergoing suffering due to any life limiting illness is eligible to receive Palliative care.

questions.question: When should Palliative care be given to a person who is suffering from a chronic illness?
questions.answer:
Palliative care should ideally begin when the diagnosis of a chronic illness is made. It should go hand in hand with Curative treatment so that the person and the family is better supported. But, as the disease advances, the role of Palliative care increases and that of curative treatment reduces.
Palliative care does not end with death too, and goes on to provide bereavement support to the family.

questions.question: Who makes up a palliative care team?
questions.answer:
The Palliative care team is led by a Nurse  who is trained in Palliative care. In Primary units whose aim is mainly to provide Basic nursing care and social support, this will be a Community nurse whereas in Secondary units whose aim is Specialised nursing care and Symptom management, this will be a Palliative care trained Staff nurse.
The Community Nurse is supported by Doctors who have received basic Palliative care training, who occasionally visit the patients who need a Doctor’s care. The Staff Nurse led team will usually have a Doctor who has specialised training in Palliative care enabling better symptom control. The Doctor might not be present in every Home care, but will be guiding the Nurses whenever needed.
Community volunteers are also an integral part of the Palliative care team.

questions.question: How does palliative care support families and caregivers?
questions.answer: Both clinical and social support is being provided by the palliative care system. Clinical support is given by the home care team as basic care, wound care, catheter care etc, also comfort devices and medicine for symptom management  at home.

questions.question: How to avail services?
questions.answer: Any one could use this grid to find the service provider near your home. It is available from all government health centres and many NGO/ CBOs working along with it.
